papers.abstract: The 3D structures of RNA play a critical role in understanding their functionalities. There exist several computational methods to study RNA 3D structures by identifying structural motifs and categorizing them into several motif families based on their structures. Although the number of such motif families is not limited, a few of them are well-studied. Out of these structural motif families, there exist several families that are visually similar or very close in structure, even with different base interactions. Alternatively, some motif families share a set of base interactions but maintain variation in their 3D formations. These similarities among different motif families, if known, can provide a better insight into the RNA 3D structural motifs as well as their characteristic functions in cell biology. In this work, we proposed a method, RNAMotifComp, that analyzes the instances of well-known structural motif families and establishes a relational graph among them. We also have designed a method to visualize the relational graph where the families are shown as nodes and their similarity information is represented as edges. We validated our discovered correlations of the motif families using RNAMotifContrast. Additionally, we used a basic Naïve Bayes classifier to show the importance of RNAMotifComp. The relational analysis explains the functional analogies of divergent motif families and illustrates the situations where the motifs of disparate families are predicted to be of the same family.

events.Text: The 3D structures of RNA play a critical role in understanding their functionalities. There exist several computational methods to study RNA 3D structures by identifying structural motifs and categorizing them into several motif families based on their structures. Although the number of such motif families is not limited, a few of them are well-studied. Out of these structural motif families, there exist several families that are visually similar or very close in structure, even with different base interactions. Alternatively, some motif families share a set of base interactions but maintain variation in their 3D formations. These similarities among different motif families, if known, can provide a better insight into the RNA 3D structural motifs as well as their characteristic functions in cell biology.

In this work, we proposed a method, RNAMotifComp, that analyzes the instances of well-known structural motif families and establishes a relational graph among them. We also have designed a method to visualize the relational graph where the families are shown as nodes and their similarity information is represented as edges.

Context: instances of well-known structural motif families
Purpose: analyzing the instances of well-known structural motif families and establishing a relational graph among them
Method: designed a method to visualize the relational graph where the families are shown as nodes and their similarity information is represented as edges
Implications: advancing our understanding of the relationships between structural motif families

events.Text: We validated our discovered correlations of the motif families using RNAMotifContrast. Additionally, we used a basic Naïve Bayes classifier to show the importance of RNAMotifComp. The relational analysis explains the functional analogies of divergent motif families and illustrates the situations where the motifs of disparate families are predicted to be of the same family.

Primary Object: their discovered correlations of the motif families

Purpose: to confirm the validity of their discovered correlations
Results: successful validation of the motif families' correlations
Analysis: This demonstrates the relationship between divergent motif families and supports the importance of RNAMotifComp
Implications: This validation enhances the reliability of motif-based analyses in comparative genomics

papers.abstract: Feature selection is a powerful dimension reduction technique which selects a subset of relevant features for model construction. Numerous feature selection methods have been proposed, but most of them fail under the high-dimensional and low-sample size (HDLSS) setting due to the challenge of overfitting. We present a deep learning-based method-GRAph Convolutional nEtwork feature Selector (GRACES) — to select important features for HDLSS data. GRACES exploits latent relations between samples with various overfitting — reducing techniques to iteratively find a set of optimal features which gives rise to the greatest decreases in the optimization loss. We demonstrate that GRACES significantly outperforms other feature selection methods on both synthetic and real-world datasets.

events.Text: Feature selection is a powerful dimension reduction technique which selects a subset of relevant features for model construction. Numerous feature selection methods have been proposed, but most of them fail under the high-dimensional and low-sample size (HDLSS) setting due to the challenge of overfitting.

We present a deep learning-based method-GRAph Convolutional nEtwork feature Selector (GRACES) — to select important features for HDLSS data. GRACES exploits latent relations between samples with various overfitting — reducing techniques to iteratively find a set of optimal features which gives rise to the greatest decreases in the optimization loss.

Context: Selecting important features for high-dimensional data

events.Text: We demonstrate that GRACES significantly outperforms other feature selection methods on both synthetic and real-world datasets.

Implications: potential for future applications and research
